title: The Story of King Samprati
subtitle: Section I.2 from JAB Manual 5th edition 2024

storyContent.tagHTML: King Samprati was a great Jain king, grandson of the legendary King Ashok. Evidence of his rule, like coins bearing Jain symbols, has been found, confirming his place in history. He became the king of Avanti in 232 B.C.

As a young prince, Samprati saw a Jain procession led by Ächärya Suhastigiri. Seeing the Ächärya sparked a faint memory, and upon asking, the Ächärya also remembered: Samprati was his disciple in a previous life.

The Ächärya told Samprati the story of that past life. During a severe famine, a poor, starving man saw that Jain monks were still receiving food. Desperate, he asked the Ächärya for help. The Ächärya, seeing his potential, told him he could get food if he became a monk.

The man eagerly agreed and was initiated. Having been starved for so long, he ate too much, which caused severe stomach pains. He endured the pain patiently and died that very night. Because he had adopted the monk's vows and borne his suffering quietly, he earned great merit and was reborn as Samprati, the grandson of King Ashok.

Hearing this, Samprati understood the power of Jainism and accepted Ächärya Suhastigiri as his guru. He even offered his kingdom to the Ächärya, who refused it, advising him instead to use his power to promote the faith.
King Samprati became a devout Jain. He was called "the Jain Ashok" for his incredible efforts to spread Jainism. He:

• Arranged for the installation of over 100,000 Tirthankar idols.
  • Constructed or renovated 36,000 temples.
  • Sent missionaries to foreign lands like Afghanistan, Nepal, and Sri Lanka.
  • Remembering his past life's hunger, he set up 700 charitable Dharamshäläs where anyone could eat for free.
King Samprati had no children, but he accepted this as a consequence of his karma. After ruling for 53 years, he died in 179 B.C. and was said to be reborn as a heavenly being.

events.title: The Starving Man
events.description: During a severe famine in Kaushämbi, a poor man is starving.

events.title: Becomes a Monk for Food
events.description: He sees Jain monks getting alms and asks Ächärya Suhastigiri for food. The Ächärya initiates him as a monk so he can receive alms.

events.title: Death and Rebirth
events.description: Having been starved, he eats too much, gets severe stomach pains, and dies. Due to his good karma from becoming a monk, he is reborn as royalty.

timelineData.era: Samprati's Rise as a Jain King

events.title: Becomes King
events.description: Samprati, grandson of King Ashok, becomes the king of Avanti in 232 B.C.

events.title: Recognizes his Guru
events.description: He sees a Jain procession led by Ächärya Suhastigiri and remembers that the Ächärya was his guru in his previous life.

events.title: Adopts Jainism
events.description: After hearing the story of his past life from the Ächärya, Samprati formally adopts Jainism as his faith.

events.title: Promotes Jainism
events.description: Following his guru's advice, he uses his power to spread Jainism throughout his kingdom and beyond.

events.title: Massive Construction Efforts
events.description: He arranges for the installation of over 100,000 Tirthankar idols and the construction or renovation of 36,000 temples.

events.title: Spreads the Message Abroad
events.description: He sends missionaries to foreign countries like Afghanistan, Nepal, Sri Lanka, and China.

events.title: Charitable Works
events.description: Remembering his starvation in a past life, he establishes 700 Dharamshäläs (charitable food halls) to feed the poor.

events.title: Death of the King
events.description: After ruling for 53 years without children, King Samprati dies.

events.title: Reborn as a Heavenly Being
events.description: Jain tradition believes that due to his immense good karma, he was reborn in a heavenly realm.

charactersData.name: King Samprati
charactersData.description: The main character, a great Jain king who was the grandson of King Ashok. In his past life, he was a starving man who became a monk for a day.

charactersData.name: Ächärya Suhastigiri
charactersData.description: A prominent Jain Ächärya who was Samprati's guru in his previous life and guided him again after he became king.

charactersData.name: King Ashok
charactersData.description: Samprati's famous grandfather, known for spreading Buddhism. Samprati is often called 'the Jain Ashok' for his similar efforts in spreading Jainism.

charactersData.name: King Kunäl
charactersData.description: The son of King Ashok and the father of King Samprati.

quizData.question: Who was King Samprati's famous grandfather?
In his previous life, why did Samprati become a monk?
quizData.answer: To get food during a severe famine.

quizData.question: What was the name of the Jain Ächärya who was Samprati's guru in two lifetimes?
How did the man in the previous life (Samprati) die?
quizData.answer: From severe stomach pains after eating too much following a long period of starvation.

quizData.question: What title is King Samprati often given, comparing him to his grandfather?
How many Tirthankar idols did Samprati arrange to have installed?
How many temples did he have built or renovated?
What did King Samprati create to help the poor and hungry?
How long did King Samprati rule his kingdom?
According to Jain tradition, what happened to King Samprati after he died?
quizData.answer: He was reborn as a heavenly being.

graphicsData.title: The Previous Life
graphicsData.description: During a great famine, a poor starving man sees that Jain monks are still able to get food. He approaches their leader, Ächärya Suhastigiri.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A starving man watches Jain monks receiving food during a famine.

graphicsData.title: A Path to Survival
graphicsData.description: The Ächärya tells him he can get food if he becomes a monk. The man gladly agrees and takes the vows, but dies from overeating.
graphicsData.dialogue: Ächärya: "You can get food if you become a monk."
graphicsData.imageAlt: The starving man is initiated as a Jain monk by the Ächärya.

graphicsData.title: A Fateful Meeting
graphicsData.description: In his next life, he is reborn as Prince Samprati. He sees the Ächärya and feels a connection, remembering his past life as the monk's disciple.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Young Prince Samprati bows before Ächärya Suhastigiri, a spark of recognition between them.

graphicsData.title: The Jain Ashok
graphicsData.description: As king, Samprati becomes a great patron of Jainism, building thousands of temples and installing over 100,000 idols.
graphicsData.imageAlt: King Samprati, a devout and regal Jain king, directs the construction of temples and statues.

graphicsData.title: Remembering Hunger
graphicsData.description: Because he remembered starving in his past life, King Samprati sets up 700 Dharamshäläs to ensure no one in his kingdom would go hungry.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A diverse group of poor people are eating happily at a charitable food hall (Dharamshälä).

graphicsData.title: A Virtuous End
graphicsData.description: After ruling for 53 years, King Samprati dies and, due to his immense good karma, is reborn as a heavenly being.
graphicsData.imageAlt: The spirit of King Samprati ascends to a heavenly realm after a long and virtuous rule.
